question: Can you summarize Myasthenia Gravis?
ideal_answer: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disease which affects the central nervous system, dorsal root ganglia of the spinal cord, heart and in certain cases the pancreas. Two thirds of MG cases result from sporadic genetic mutations, not inheritance, but their offspring may inherit it from them.

snippets.text: Myasthenia gravis is a rare and invalidating disease affecting the neuromuscular junction of voluntary muscles. The classical form of this autoimmune disease is characterized by the presence of antibodies against the most abundant protein in the neuromuscular junction, the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor.

Myasthenia gravis (MG) and Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) are the most common disorders of neuromuscular transmission in clinical practice. Disorders of the neuromuscular junction (NMJ) are characterized by fluctuating and fatigable weakness and include autoimmune, toxic, and genetic conditions.
